lcInstruction.p: A conkeyref is a content reference that uses a key instead of a file path. In normal use, a content reference to an element in another file might look like this:
This conref pulls a <ul> element from a warehouse topic that contains reusable elements relevant to domestic ducks.

If the topic containing this conref needs to be reusable, the hard-coded filename might be a problem. To use the reusable topic in a map that discusses wild ducks, the conref needs to point to a different warehouse topic file (wild_duck_warehouse.dita).
Rather than hard code the path to a file, you can use the conkeyref attribute to create a content reference that uses a key, rather than a filename.
To use a conkeyref, start by defining a key (in the map used for domestic ducks):
Within domestic_duck_warehouse.dita, make sure there is an unordered list with the id="diet_list".
To ensure our topic is reusable, use a conkeyref:
When the topic containing the conkeyref is processed, the key diet_warehouse is replace with the current key definition, which is domestic_duck_warehouse.dita.

To reuse the topic containing the conkeyref, add a <keydef> for the diet_warehouse key to the map for wild duck content, but in this <keydef>, the href attribute points to the warehouse topic file wild_duck_warehouse.dita:
All the same rules that apply to conrefs still apply to conkeyrefs

ul.li: The referencing element must be the same type (element name) as the referenced element.
The referencing element must be valid (for instance a <ul> element must contain at least one <li> element).
